content:
# Age and COVID-19

No matter what your age, if you get infected with COVID-19, you may infect people you care about, you may feel very ill and symptoms may take up to 14 days to appear. Call your public health authority and stay home if you have the following symptoms:
 
* Fever.
* New or worsening cough. 
* Fatigue or weakness. 
* Muscle or body aches and pains.
* Headache. 
* Loss of taste or smell. 
* Difficulty breathing.

Find a video testimonial and transcript here from 24-year old Janis who had COVID-19: 
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/video/covid-19-coming-back-story-janis.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/video/covid-19-coming-back-story-janis.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-age&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

# Anxiety and isolation during COVID-19

COVID-19 is affecting the mental health of many people. It is common to feel anxious and isolated. Wellness Together Canada portal has online mental health and substance use support and counselling.

content:
# A non-medical mask can help protect those around you

In situations where physical distancing is difficult to maintain, wearing a non-medical mask or face covering (e.g. homemade cloth mask, dust mask, bandana) when you are in a public place is an additional measure that you can take to protect the people around you. It may also stop you from touching your nose or mouth, which are ways the COVID-19 virus can get into your body. Continue to stay at home, wash your hands and do your part.

Full details can be found here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks.html#wm](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks.html#wm?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-Masks&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=masks-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

# Know when you need to practise physical distancing, quarantine (self-isolation) and isolation

Everyone needs to practice physical distancing, but did you know that there is a difference between quarantine (self-isolation) and isolation? It is important to note under which circumstances these practices may apply to you. These measures are in place to protect the health and safety of the public.

Full details can be found here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks.html#self](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks.html#self?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-definitions&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=terms&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

Wondering how to help with Canada's COVID-19 effort? Here are some concrete, meaningful ways to contribute to our communities:
* Volunteering to help with Canada's response to COVID-19
* Donating personal protective equipment or other medical supplies

content:
# Are you or someone you know at a higher risk of severe illness from COVID-19?

If you are an older adult, have a medical condition or a weakened immune system, you are more at risk of developing severe complications from COVID-19. There are actions you can take to reduce your risk of getting sick. If possible, stay at home. If you must go out, practise strict physical distancing.

Full details can be found here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/people-high-risk-for-severe-illness-covid-19.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/people-high-risk-for-severe-illness-covid-19.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-High-risk-people&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# Mandatory non-medical masks or face coverings for air travel

Effective April 20, 2020, if you are departing or arriving at Canadian airports by air, you will need to show that you have a face covering or non-medical mask to cover your nose and mouth during travel. Otherwise, you will not be allowed to continue on your journey.

Full details can be found here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html?topic=tilelink#a4](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html?topic=tilelink&utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-masks-travel&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#a4)

content:
# Can I go for a walk?

Outdoor exercise can contribute to your overall physical and mental health. You can go for a walk if you:
* have not been diagnosed with COVID-19
* do not have symptoms of COVID-19
* have not travelled outside of Canada in the past 14 days

If you go out for a walk, do not congregate and always practise physical distancing by keeping at least 2 metres apart from others at all times.

Full details can be found here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks.html?topic=tilelink#p](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks.html?topic=tilelink&utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-walking&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#p)

content:
# Pregnancy, childbirth and caring for newborns during COVID-19

COVID-19 is a new disease and we are still learning how it affects pregnancy, childbirth and newborns. Currently there is:
* no evidence pregnant women are at a higher risk of becoming seriously ill from COVID-9
* no evidence a developing child could be negatively affected by COVID-19
* no evidence mother-to-child transmission of COVID-19 occurs through childbirth 
* no evidence the virus that causes COVID-19 is found in breast milk

Full details can be found here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/pregnancy-advise-mothers.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/pregnancy-advise-mothers.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-pregnancy&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

# Are you losing income because of COVID-19?

If you reside in Canada and have lost income because of COVID-19, the Canada Emergency Response Benefit (CERB) may help you with temporary income support. The CERB provides $500 a week for up to 16 weeks.

Full details can be found here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/services/benefits/ei/cerb-application.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/services/benefits/ei/cerb-application.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-cerb&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

You can help slow the spread of COVID-19 by making a conscious effort to keep a physical distance from others. Physical distancing is proven to be one of the most effective ways to reduce the spread of illness during an outbreak.

content:
# Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine can have serious side effects

No medicines have been approved by Health Canada to prevent, treat or cure COVID-19. Drugs such as chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine can have serious side effects and should be used only under the supervision of a physician.

Full details can be found here: [https://healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72885a-eng.php](https://healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72885a-eng.php?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-medicines&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=infographic&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# Symptoms of COVID-19

You may not know you have COVID-19 because symptoms can be similar to those of a cold or flu. If you have fever, cough or difficulty breathing, have travelled outside of Canada in the last 14 days, or have been in contact with someone diagnosed with COVID-19, please contact a healthcare professional.  

You can also take a self-assessment if you think you may have COVID-19 here: [https://ca.thrive.health/covid19/en](https://ca.thrive.health/covid19/en?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-symptomsandtreatment&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=selfassessment-tool&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# Homemade hand sanitizers may present health risks

Homemade sanitizers may not be effective in killing the coronavirus that causes COVID-19 and may pose other health risks. If you have made or used homemade hand sanitizer products, stop using them.

It is recommended that you wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If this is not possible, use a Health Canada approved alcohol-based hand sanitizer, with at least 60% alcohol.

Full details can be found here: [https://healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72687a-eng.php](https://healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72687a-eng.php?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-handsanitizer&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=recall-alert&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# Essential workers may have exemptions to mandatory quarantine.

Are you returning to or entering Canada for essential work and have no COVID-19 symptoms? If so, you may not have to quarantine.
If you are an essential worker, you are only exempt from mandatory quarantine under strict conditions:
* If you have no symptoms (asymptomatic).
* if you are travelling on business or for the reason of exemption.
* The purpose of your travel is defined as essential in the Emergency order.

Essential workers as determined by province, or by Public Safety are NOT all exempt. 
Full details on quarantine exemption can be found here: 
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/covid-19-information-essential-service-workers.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/covid-19-information-essential-service-workers.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-essential-workers-2&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
You may not know that you have COVID-19 because some symptoms are the same as a cold or flu. Here are some signs of COVID-19 to look for:

* Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing.
* Temperature equal to or over 38°C.
* New loss of smell or taste.
* Abdominal pain, diarrhea, vomiting.
* Fatigue or weakness.

If you have some of these symptoms, you have travelled outside of Canada in the last 14 days, or you have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19, please contact a healthcare professional. 

Full details can be found here: 
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms.html] (https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-symptoms-update-1&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
If you are caring for a person who has tested positive for COVID-19, here are a few ways you can help protect yourself and others in your home and community:
 
* Make sure that only one healthy person is a caregiver for the ill person
* Use a bathroom that is not used by the ill person, if possible
* Wear a mask or face covering with two layers of tightly woven fabric
* Stay away from animals that were in contact with the ill person
 
Find full details here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/how-to-care-for-person-with-covid-19-at-home-advice-for-caregivers.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/how-to-care-for-person-with-covid-19-at-home-advice-for-caregivers.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-caregiving2&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# Caring for pets during COVID-19

There have been reports of people spreading COVID-19 to their pet dog or cat. If you have COVID-19 symptoms or you are self-isolating because you have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19, you should: 

* Not get close to animals.
* Keep clean and make sure you wash your hands thoroughly and a few times a day.
* Have someone in your household take care of your animals, if possible.
* Keep your animals away from people and animals that are outside of the household.

Find full details here: 
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/animals-covid-19.html#a2](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/animals-covid-19.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-pets-2&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#a2)

content:
# Gathering in outdoor spaces

It's important to use protective measures while in public outdoor spaces. This includes areas like:
* Trails.
* Beaches.
* Campgrounds.
* Parks, including playgrounds and dog parks.
 
Measures you can take outdoors include:
* Avoiding large groups or crowding.
* Washing or sanitizing your hands after touching common surfaces.
* Playing only low-contact recreational sports where you can keep a 2-metre distance from other players.

Full details can be found here: 
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/going-out-personal-social-activities-during-pandemic.html#a9](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/going-out-personal-social-activities-during-pandemic.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-gathering-outdoors&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#a9)

content:
# Hosting a small gathering safely

When hosting a small gathering, remind your guests to follow all recommended practices for protecting themselves and others. In addition to these general precautions, take the following measures when hosting small gatherings:
* Host your gathering outdoors.
* Make sure the size of your gathering meets local public health authority guidelines.
* For gatherings where food or drinks are served: use disposable dishes and cutlery, encourage guests to bring their own food and drinks and avoid sharing snack bowls or using hands to eat from the same bowl.
* Promote hand hygiene by providing: liquid soap, no-touch waste containers, and alcohol-based hand sanitizer.

Full details can be found here: 
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/going-out-personal-social-activities-during-pandemic.html#a6](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/going-out-personal-social-activities-during-pandemic.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-small-gatherings&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#a6)

content:
#Avoid high risk settings

Help to lower the spread of COVID-19 and protect the health and safety of everyone in your community. Stay away from the three “Cs” of high risk settings and situations which are:

* Closed spaces with poor ventilation. 
* Crowded places with large numbers of people gathered. 
* Close contact where you can’t stay 2 metres away from others.

Full details can be found here: 
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2020/07/information-and-resources-on-covid-19-epidemiology-and-reducing-your-risks-for-infection-and-spreading-the-virus.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2020/07/information-and-resources-on-covid-19-epidemiology-and-reducing-your-risks-for-infection-and-spreading-the-virus.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-high-risk-settings&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

# Bullying and personal protective equipment

Bullying can be very hard on children. During this COVID-19 pandemic, they may be targeted for wearing personal protective equipment. They may also be targeted because of their anxiety and fears about the virus and other differences. You can help children by learning more about what to do during these times. 
Find details on how to spot bullying and what to do about it here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/bullying/how-recognize-bullying.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/bullying/how-recognize-bullying.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-mask-bullying&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# Food safety and COVID-19 

You are unlikely to be infected with the COVID-19 virus when eating food or handling food packaging. But you can lower your risk of infection by: 
* Using hand sanitizers at the entrance of a food store, if they are available. 
* Keeping your distance from other people while shopping (at least 2 arms lengths, approximately 2 metres).
*Washing your hands with soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds before and after handling food and food packaging. If you do not have running water, use one of our approved sanitizers.
* Washing your fruits and vegetables under running water. It is not recommended to use soap, chlorine or other chemicals. Fresh vegetables and fruit can absorb chemicals that are not intended for you  to eat.
 
Find more details here:
[https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/food-nutrition/food-safety/covid19.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/food-nutrition/food-safety/covid19.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-food-safety2&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

A guidance document is available for death care services during the COVID-19 pandemic.The Public Health Agency of Canada, Canadian public health, and experts in stopping infections and funeral services made this guidance document. It is for:
* Loved ones.
* Funeral homes.

* Medical examiners. 
* Coroners.
* Medical personnel. 
* People who may handle dead bodies infected with COVID-19 in far away and isolated communities.

# Going out Safely

Going out safely during COVID-19 means taking steps to protect yourself and others.

Your actions matter. Make informed choices :

* Wear a non-medical mask.
* Continue practicing physical distancing.
* Wash your hands often.
* Stay home if you have symptoms.
* Follow advice from your local public health authority.

Make informed choices to keep yourself and others safe:
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/going-out-personal-social-activities-during-pandemic.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/going-out-personal-social-activities-during-pandemic.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-going-out&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# Halloween during the COVID-19 pandemic

Halloween celebrations will vary depending on the spread of COVID-19 in your area. Your local public health authority will make recommendations and decisions around Halloween festivities, including limitations or cancellation. These recommendations and decisions will be based on:

* How much the disease is spreading in the local area.
* Public health measures in effect like gathering size limits.
 
Only participate in trick-or-treating activities if your local public health authority allows it.

Public Health Authority:
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/provincial-territorial-resources-covid-19.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/provincial-territorial-resources-covid-19.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-halloween-safety&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

# Hand sanitizers and hard surface disinfectants

Hand sanitizers and hard surface disinfectants do not claim to kill coronaviruses. But they can help to lower the spread of microorganisms. Learn about the best ways to clean your skin and the surfaces in your area to lower your risk of COVID-19 infection. 

Find more details here:

[https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/drugs-health-products/disinfectants/covid-19.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/drugs-health-products/disinfectants/covid-19.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-hand-sanitizers2&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

# Health and Mindfulness during COVID-19

The Wellness Together Canada portal provides free, credible resources and support, including confidential counselling, to take care of your mental health during COVID-19. When you feel stressed or overwhelmed, practicing daily mindfulness may help. Mindwell U has plenty of resources to get you started, like:

* Live drop-in classes.
* Videos and infographics.
* 5-minute exercises to practice in the moment.

Visit wellnesstogether.ca for more information.

See the full list for taking care of yourself here:
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/mental-health.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/mental-health.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-mindfulness&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# How to wash hands

Washing your hands is one of the best ways to make sure that you are not spreading the virus. As more of us enter the workplace and schools it is important to know how to do it right.  Be sure to:

* Wash your hands many times a day.
* Wash all parts of your hand.
* Wash using both soap and water.
* Wash for at least 20 seconds.

Learn more by watching this helpful video: 
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/video/covid-19-hand-washing.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/video/covid-19-hand-washing.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-wash-hands&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# How to isolate at home

If you have tested positive for COVID-19 or have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19, you should isolate for 14 days in your home. Isolating at home means:
* Do not leave home unless directed to do so (for example, to seek medical care while wearing protective equipment).
* Do not use public transportation (for example, buses, subways, taxis).
* Arrange to have groceries and supplies dropped off at your door to minimize contact.
* Stay in a separate room and use a separate bathroom from others in your home, if possible.
 
Find more details here:  
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/health-professionals/interim-guidance-cases-contacts.html#appex1](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/health-professionals/interim-guidance-cases-contacts.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-isolate-home&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#appex1)

content:
# Continue to protect those at high risk for severe illness from COVID-19

Coronavirus can result in severe illness for some people in our communities.  Those that are more at risk of developing severe complications from COVID-19 are people who:
* Have a medical condition.
* Have a weakened immune system. 
* Are an older adult.

If you are at higher risk, you should continue to stay home as much as possible, and if you must go out, practise strict physical distancing.
Full details can be found here:
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/people-high-risk-for-severe-illness-covid-19.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/people-high-risk-for-severe-illness-covid-19.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-High-risk-people&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# Travelling to Canada during the pandemic?

We continue to have enhanced border measures in place in an effort to reduce the spread of COVID-19.
As part of these measures, all travellers entering Canada must provide information including contact information, updates on symptoms, and details of their plans for the mandatory quarantine.

Full details on current travel restrictions to Canada and requirements for a mandatory 14-day isolation and quarantine after entry are available here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html#ua](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-Travel-advisories2&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#ua)

# COVID-19 and family violence

An increase in family violence has been reported since the start of the pandemic. If you, or someone you know, is experiencing family violence, there are services to help you stay safe or provide help.

# Your safety and security outside Canada during COVID-19

Avoid non-essential travel outside of Canada until further notice. If you choose to travel despite these advisories you may:
* Face sudden border or airspace closures.
* Not be covered by your travel or medical insurance.
* Have difficulty accessing essential products and services.

Full details can be found here:
[https://travel.gc.ca/travelling/advisories](https://travel.gc.ca/travelling/advisories?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-travel-advisories&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
#New exemptions to travel restrictions

Immediate family members of a Canadian citizen or permanent resident may now be eligible to enter Canada. To be eligible, you must provide evidence that:

* You are an immediate family member of a Canadian citizen or permanent resident.
* You will be staying in Canada for at least 15 days.

You must also have a quarantine plan that shows how you will quarantine for 14 days when you arrive in Canada. 

Full details can be found here:
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html#foreign](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-immediate-family&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#foreign)

content:
# Physical distancing to contain the spread of COVID-19

As stores and parks begin to reopen across the country, it is important to continue to physically distance, including:
* Avoiding crowded places and gatherings.
* Avoiding common greetings, such as handshakes.
* Limiting contact with people at higher risk.
* Keeping a distance of at least 2 arms length from others.

Physical distancing is proven to be one of the most effective ways to reduce the spread of illness during an outbreak.

Full details can be found here:
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/social-distancing.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/social-distancing.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-physical-distancing&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# When to wear a non-medical mask

Wearing a non-medical mask or face covering is recommended when it may not be possible to physical distance from others, particularly in crowded public settings, such as:
* Stores.
* Shopping areas.
* Public transportation.

Wearing a mask alone will not prevent the spread of COVID-19. Continue to wash your hands frequently and keep your distance from others.

Details on how to properly wear a mask can be found here:
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-when-wear-mask&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

# How you can help protect Canada’s drug supply

The COVID-19 pandemic has shifted the supply and demand of some drugs. While supply levels are stabilizing, pressures continue for some important medicines. You can help protect Canada's drug supply by not buying more medication than usual. Health Canada will continue to watch the drug supply and take necessary actions if needed.

For full details see:
[https://healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/73223a-eng.php](https://healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/73223a-eng.php?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-drug-supply&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# Get reliable information on COVID-19

If you are looking for information on COVID-19, turn to reliable sources such as the Public Health Agency of Canada and provincial and territorial public health authorities. If you are finding that the news media is making you feel anxious, take a break from it.

For more information on how you can protect yourself and your family see: [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/measures-reduce-community.html#fi](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/measures-reduce-community.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-reliable-info&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#fi)

content:
# Risks of health products that make false claims about COVID-19

While research into the treatment and prevention of COVID-19 is being conducted, Health Canada has not approved any product to prevent, treat or cure COVID-19. If you have purchased a product claiming to do so, stop using it immediately. Consult a health care professional if you have any concerns. 

Full details can be found here:
[https://www.healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72659a-eng.php](https://www.healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72659a-eng.php?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-false-claims&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

# Changes to passport services during COVID-19

Passport services continue to be available if you need to travel urgently.  If not, please wait until services return to normal. If you applied and do not need to travel urgently, your application will be processed when services resume.

As workplaces begin to reopen, it is important that good practices are in place to prevent the spread of COVID-19. content:
# Make child and youth settings safer

Settings for children and youth have started to reopen. To lower the risk of spreading COVID-19, it’s important for school boards, operators, staff and volunteers to learn how to make things safer. 

Settings for children and youth include:

* Early learning.
* Daycare centres.
* Schools (K-12).
* Day programs.
* Summer camps.
* Other settings where children and youth are found.

Find more useful information at: 
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/guidance-documents/covid-19-risk-mitigation-tool-child-youth-settings-operating-during-pandemic.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/guidance-documents/covid-19-risk-mitigation-tool-child-youth-settings-operating-during-pandemic.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-settings-schools&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# Are you an employer whose business has been affected by COVID-19?

If you are a Canadian employer and your business has lost revenue because of COVID-19, you may be eligible for the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy (CEWS). The CEWS provides 75% of employee wages for up to 12 weeks, retroactive from March 15, 2020, to June 6, 2020.

Full details can be found here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/revenue-agency/services/subsidy/emergency-wage-subsidy.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/revenue-agency/services/subsidy/emergency-wage-subsidy.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-CEWS&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# Homemade hand sanitizers may present health risks
Homemade sanitizers may not be effective in killing the coronavirus that causes COVID-19 and may pose other health risks. If you have made or used homemade hand sanitizer products, stop using them.

It is recommended that you wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If this is not possible, use a Health Canada approved alcohol-based hand sanitizer, with at least 60% alcohol.

Full details can be found here: 
[https://healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72687a-eng.php](https://healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72687a-eng.php?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-handsanitizer&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=recall-alert&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# Caring for pets during COVID-19

There have been reports of people with COVID-19 spreading the virus to their pet dog or cat. If you have COVID-19 symptoms or are self-isolating due to contact with a COVID-19 case, until your illness is resolved you should:
* Avoid close contact with animals. 
* Practice good hygiene, including hand washing.
* If possible, have another member of your household care for your animals.
* Restrict your animal's contact with other people and animals outside the household.

Full details can be found here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/animals-covid-19.html#a2](https://www.canada.ca/fr/sante-publique/services/maladies/2019-nouveau-coronavirus/prevention-risques/animaux-covid-19.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-pets&utm_medium=eml-fr&utm_content=landing-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#a2)

content:
# Support for students and new graduates during COVID-19

Are you a student or recent graduate unable to work due to COVID-19? You may be eligible for the Canada Emergency Student Benefit (CESB). From May to August 2020, the CESB provides a payment of:
* $1,250 for each 4-week period, or
* $2,000 for each 4-week period if you have dependants or a disability.

Full details can be found here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/revenue-agency/services/benefits/emergency-student-benefit.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/revenue-agency/services/benefits/emergency-student-benefit.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-cesb&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

As schools and businesses begin to reopen in some provinces and territories, it is important that you are ready if there is illness in your community or home. Have supplies on hand and limit the spread of COVID-19 by continuing to physically distance and wash your hands.

content:
# Essential workers exempt from mandatory self-isolation

As more workplaces open, essential travel is expected to increase. If you are returning to or entering Canada for essential work and have no COVID-19 symptoms, you may not need to self-isolate. Monitor your health for 14 days after each entry and follow local public health guidance.

Full details can be found here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/covid-19-information-essential-service-workers.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/covid-19-information-essential-service-workers.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-essential-workers&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

# Clean high touch surfaces to limit the spread of COVID-19

Coronaviruses can be easily killed with the appropriate disinfectant. To limit the spread of COVID-19, clean high touch surfaces often. Use household cleaners or diluted bleach according to the label directions.

# Flying within Canada

All passengers flying within Canada will be subject to a health check prior to boarding. You will not be permitted to board if you: 
* show any symptoms of COVID-19 or
* have been refused boarding in the past 14 days due to a medical reason related to COVID-19 or
* are subject to a provincial or local public health order

content:
# Protect yourself and your family from poisonings

The COVID-19 pandemic has increased the use of household cleaning products, bleaches, disinfectants, and hand sanitizers. Between February and March, poison centres received 58% more reports of exposure to these products, compared with the same period last year.

To keep your home and family safe, read and follow the directions on product labels.

Find more information on how to safely use these products here: [https://healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72983a-eng.php](https://healthycanadians.gc.ca/recall-alert-rappel-avis/hc-sc/2020/72983a-eng.php?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-poisonings&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
#Pregnancy, childbirth and caring for newborns during COVID-19

COVID-19 is a new virus and we are still learning how it may or may not affect pregnancy, childbirth and newborns. 

At this time there is:

* No proof that pregnant women are at a higher risk of becoming ill from COVID-19.
* No proof that COVID-19 could affect a developing child.
* No proof that mother-to-child infection of COVID-19 happens through childbirth. 
* No proof that the virus that causes COVID-19 could be in breast milk.

Find full details here: 
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/pregnancy-advise-mothers.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/pregnancy-advise-mothers.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-pregnancy2&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

# Protecting child/youth settings

It may be hard to keep children and youth away from each other and their shared surfaces. But, to make things safer and to help lower the spread of COVID-19, you can:

* Guide children and youth to have less person-to-person contact with others.
* Teach children how to spot COVID-19 symptoms and to tell parents/guardians/teachers right away if they have them. 
* Put up signs everywhere that list the symptoms and keep children at home when they are sick.
* Remind everyone to wash their hands often and avoid touching their face.

Find more ideas here:  [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/guidance-documents/covid-19-risk-mitigation-tool-child-youth-settings-operating-during-pandemic.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/guidance-documents/covid-19-risk-mitigation-tool-child-youth-settings-operating-during-pandemic.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-child-youth-settings&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# Protecting yourself outside

When you go outside to parks, trails, dog parks, playgrounds and recreational spaces, you need to protect yourself from COVID-19.  You can do this by:
* Playing only low-contact recreational sports where you can keep a 2-metre distance from other players.
* Staying away from large groups or crowds at lookout points, trails, etc.
* Carrying water bottles and not using public drinking fountains.
* Washing or sanitizing hands after touching surfaces such as:
   * park benches.
   * public washrooms.
   * playground equipment.
 
Find more details here: 
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/going-out-personal-social-activities-during-pandemic.html#a9

content:
# Safeguard group living settings

People who live together but are not in the same family unit are in a group living setting. In these settings, everyone can do their part to lower the risk of infection from COVID-19. 

Group living settings include:
* student residences.
* construction trailers.
* closed settings, such as :residential care, correctional facilities and long-term care facilities.
* group homes for people with disabilities.
* shelters for people who are homeless and more. 
 
Find more details here:

content:
# Safeguard group living settings

People who live together but are not in the same family unit are in a group living setting. In these settings, everyone can do their part to lower the risk of infection from COVID-19. 

Group living settings include:
 
* student residences.
* construction trailers.
* closed settings, such as :residential care, correctional facilities and long-term care facilities.
* group homes for people with disabilities.
* shelters for people who are homeless and more. 
 
Find more details here:  
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/measures-reduce-community.html#g](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/measures-reduce-community.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-safeguard-group-living&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#g)

content:
# Holiday shopping safety

The holiday season is a popular time for shopping, and things are different this year. Remember to follow COVID-19 safety measures while shopping in public such as wearing a mask and cleaning your hands often.

A good idea is to shop online or use curbside pick-up whenever possible. If you do shop in person:
* Plan ahead to avoid crowds.
* Limit the number of people you shop with.

For more information on how to help reduce the spread of COVID-19 during the holidays, visit:
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/guidance-documents/plan-safe-holiday-celebration.html#a6](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/guidance-documents/plan-safe-holiday-celebration.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-holiday-shopping&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#a6)

# School activities - COVID-19

Physical activity in schools is healthy and it shouldn’t stop during COVID-19. But there are ways to lower the risk of spreading the virus by:

* Physical distancing.
* Not sharing water bottles.
* Frequent sanitization of equipment.
* Checking the size of rooms and making sure they have good air circulation; and
* Following the advice of your local public health authority.

 Full details can be found here:  [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/health-professionals/guidance-schools-childcare-programs.html#a4](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/health-professionals/guidance-schools-childcare-programs.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-school-activities&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#a4)

content:
# School cafeterias - COVID-19 

There are many different food programs and cafeterias in schools across Canada. Here are a few ways that some schools might help to stop the spread of COVID-19 in eating areas:
* Lower the number of individuals allowed in cafeterias at the same time.
* Make sure there is at least 2-metres distance between seats in cafeterias. 
* Add signs and floor markings. These will remind staff and students to practice social distancing. It will also remind them of one direction flows of traffic in narrow aisles and stairways. 
* Add more accessible hand sanitizer stations in the cafeteria.
* Ask everyone to eat meals in classrooms or outdoors instead of in the cafeteria.

Find more details and tips here: 
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/health-professionals/guidance-schools-childcare-programs.html#a4](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/health-professionals/guidance-schools-childcare-programs.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-school-cafeterias&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#a4)

content:
# If you have symptoms - COVID-19

You can have COVID-19 and have no symptoms. You can also have mild to severe symptoms or symptoms that seem like the flu or other illnesses. Reach out to a public health authority for information or get tested if your symptoms include: 

Most common symptoms:

* New or worsening cough.
* Feeling feverish.
* Fatigue or weakness.
 
Less common symptoms:
 
* Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing.
* temperature equal to or over 38°C.
* Chills.
* Muscle or body aches.
* New loss of smell or taste and more.
 
Find more details here on the symptoms and what to do: https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms.html#p](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-symptoms-update-3&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#p)

content:
# Testing for COVID-19 in Canada

Testing is the only way to confirm whether you have COVID-19. It is important to know if you are infected so that you can protect your family and the people in your community. 

Testing helps to lower the spread of the virus

Testing tells us:
* who has the virus.
* how much the virus may be spreading in our communities.
 
All tests must be done by a health care professional. At-home sample collection test kits or home test kits have not been authorized for sale. 

Details on COVID-19 testing in Canada can be found here: 
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-Testing&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# When to wear a non-medical mask

Wearing a non-medical mask or face covering is recommended when it may not be possible to physical distance from others, particularly in crowded public settings, such as:
* Stores.
* Shopping areas.
* Public transportation.

Wearing a mask alone will not prevent the spread of COVID-19. Continue to wash your hands frequently and keep your distance from others.

Details on how to properly wear a mask can be found here:
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-when-wear-mask&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# Tips for staying active safely during COVID-19

Whether at home or outdoors, keep these tips in mind to help stay safe while exercising during COVID-19:

At home:

* Exercise alone, with a friend, or in a small group.
* Practice good hygiene by cleaning and disinfecting any equipment you use alone or with others.

Outdoors:

* Engage in non-contact activities that allow spacing of 6 feet between people.
* When out for a run, practice good respiratory etiquette by avoiding passing pedestrians.
* When out for a walk, keep your distance from runners and cyclists.


Full details here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/mental-health.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/mental-health.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-physical-activity-3&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920).

# Travel and Quarantine Information - COVID-19

You may be required to isolate or quarantine yourself right away to stop the spread of COVID-19 and protect the health and safety of your community. You will need to quarantine for 14 days if you:

* Are returning from travel outside of Canada.
* You had close contact with someone who has or is suspected of having COVID-19. 
* Your local public health authority tells you that you may have been exposed.
 
Find more details here:
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html#a1.5](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-travel-quarantine-information&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#a1.5)

# Travellers departing Canada and COVID-19 

Canadian citizens and permanent residents are advised to 
avoid all non-essential travel outside of Canada until further
notice to limit the spread of COVID-19.

The best way to protect yourself, your family and those
most at risk of severe illness from COVID-19 in your
communities is to choose to stay in Canada. 

Full details can be found here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html#_Travellers_departing_Canada#a3](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-travel-advisories-4&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page-travellers&utm_campaign=covid-1920#_Travellers_departing_Canada#a3)

content:
# Update: Hosting a small gathering 

It is best to stay home and only be in close contact with people in your bubble or when you’re getting essential products or services. But if you must plan a small event it is important to remember to: 

* Make sure the size of your gathering meets local public health authority guidelines.
* Stay 2 metres apart.
* Wear a mask.
* Use disposable dishes and cutlery.
* Ask guests to bring their own food and drinks and avoid sharing snack bowls or using hands to eat from the same bowl.
* Have liquid soap, no-touch waste containers, and alcohol-based hand sanitizer on hand for guests to use.
 
Find more details here:  
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/going-out-personal-social-activities-during-pandemic.html#a6](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/going-out-personal-social-activities-during-pandemic.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-small-gatherings-2&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920#a6)

content:
# Safe Use of Non-Medical Masks and Face Coverings

Wearing a non-medical mask or face covering when you can’t maintain a 2-metre distance from others is mandatory. Here are a few tips on how they can safely be used:
*  Ensure your mask is made of at least two layers of tightly woven fabric.
*  Wash your hands or use alcohol-based hand sanitizer before and after touching the mask or face covering.
* Use the ear loops or ties to put on and remove the mask.
*  Make sure your nose and mouth are fully covered.

Wearing a non-medical mask or face covering alone will not prevent the spread of COVID-19. For complete information, including guidance on how to clean, store and dispose of masks and face coverings, visit [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/covid-19-safely-use-non-medical-mask-face-covering.html?utm_source=info-covid-email&utm_medium=canada.ca-link-1&utm_content=hc-jul-28-en&utm_campaign=covid-1920](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/covid-19-safely-use-non-medical-mask-face-covering.html?utm_source=info-covid-email&utm_medium=canada.ca-link-1&utm_content=hc-jul-28-en&utm_campaign=covid-1920&utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-mask-2&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# Eligible wages time frame extended for the Wage Earner Protection Program

Because of the COVID-19 pandemic many businesses are facing financial hardship. Some may have become insolvent, but with less access to the courts, many are experiencing delays in filing for bankruptcy or receivership.

That is why the eligible wages period for the Wage Earner Protection Program (WEPP) has been extended by up to 6 months. This extension will help to ensure that any delays in bankruptcy or receivership proceedings, due to the pandemic, will not affect workers’ eligibility for the WEPP.

Full details on the WEPP and how to apply for it can be found here:
[https://www.canada.ca/en/employment-social-development/services/labour-standards/reports/wage-protection.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/employment-social-development/services/labour-standards/reports/wage-protection.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-wepp-extension&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

Consult the changes to the Wage Earner Protection Program for employees:
[https://www.canada.ca/en/employment-social-development/services/wage-earner-protection/employee/eligibility.html#h2.01-h3.01](https://www.canada.ca/en/employment-social-development/services/wage-earner-protection/employee/eligibility.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-wepp-extension&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=support-employee&utm_campaign=covid-1920#h2.01-h3.01)

# When to wash your hands

To help stop the spread of COVID-19, it is very important to wash your hands often and not touch your face. When exiting your home, you may come into contact with many people and surfaces that may have the virus. Some infected surfaces may include:

* Bank and debit machines.
* Coffee cups.
* Counter tops.
* Money.

Watch this video to learn more about the importance of washing your hands often. 
[https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/video/wash-hands-reduce-spread-covid-19.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/video/wash-hands-reduce-spread-covid-19.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-wash-hands-2&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)

content:
# When to stay home

During the COVID-19 pandemic, it’s important to know when to seek testing and care and when to stay home. Stay home, keep away from others and connect with people by phone or online if:
* You have symptoms, even if they are mild.
* You think you may have been exposed to the virus and you have symptoms. Then contact your local public health authority and get tested.
 
Find more details here: [https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2020/07/information-and-resources-on-covid-19-epidemiology-and-reducing-your-risks-for-infection-and-spreading-the-virus.html](https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2020/07/information-and-resources-on-covid-19-epidemiology-and-reducing-your-risks-for-infection-and-spreading-the-virus.html?utm_source=getupdatesoncovid19-when-stay-home&utm_medium=eml&utm_content=info-page&utm_campaign=covid-1920)
